div.head: THE GUAHIBI MOTHER.
div.p:
In 1797, the missionary of San Fernando
had led his Indians to the banks of the
Rio Guaviare, on one of those hostile oc-
casions, which are prohibited alike by
religion and the Spanish laws. They found,
in an ItalianIndian hut, a Guahiba mother with
three children, two of whom were still in-
fants. They were occupied in preparing
the flour of Cassava. Resistance was im-
possible; the father was gone to fish, the
unhappy mother tried in vain to flee with
her children. Scarcely had she reached
the Savannah, when she was seized by the
Indians of the mission, who hunt men with
the ferocity of the whites and the negroes
in Africa. The wretched mother and her
children were bound, and dragged to the
bank of the river. The monk, seated in
his boat, waited the issue of this expedition
of barbarity, and of which he partook not
the danger. Had the mother made too
violent a resistance, the Indians would
unquestionably have killed her, for any
excess is permitted them when they go to
the conquest of souls, as they term it, (a la
conquista espiritual), and it is children
whom they particularly seek to capture, in
order to treat them, in the mission, as
poitos, or slaves of the Christians. The
prisoners were carried to San Fernando, in
the hope, that in the event of escape, the
mother would be unable to find her way
back to her house, by land.

Far from those children who had accom-
panied their father on the day on which
she had been carried off, this unhappy
woman shewed signs of the deepest de-
spair. She attempted to take back to her
family the children who had been thus
brutally snatched away by the missionary,
and fled with them repeatedly from the
village of San Fernando, but the Indians
never failed to seize her anew; and the
missionary, after having caused the poor
wretch to be mercilessly beaten, took the
cruel resolution of separating the mother
from the two children, who had been car-
ried off with her. She was now conveyed
alone toward the mission of the Rio Negro,
going up the river Atabapo; slightly bound,
she was seated at the bow of the boat,
utterly ignorant of the fate that awaited
her; but she judged, by the direction of
the sun, that she was removed farther and
farther from her hut and her native coun-
try. Seizing a favourable opportunity,
she succeeded in breaking her bonds, threw
herself into the water, and swam to the
left bank of the river. The current car-
ried her to a shelf of rock, which bears her
name to this day. Here she landed, and
took shelter in the woods, but the presi-
dent of the missions, astonished at her cou-
rage, ordered his Indians to row to the
shore, and followed the traces of the Gua-
hibi. In the evening the unhappy creature
was brought back. Stretched upon the
rock, still called (la piedra de la Madre),
a cruel punishment was inflicted on her
with those straps of manatee leather, which
serve for whips in that country, and with
which the Alcades are always furnished;
and the unhappy woman, her hands tied
behind her back with strong stalks of ma-
vacure, was then dragged to the mission
of Javita.

She was there thrown into one of the
caravanseras that are called Casa del Rey.
It was during the rainy season, when the
night was profoundly dark, forests, till
then, believed to be impenetrable, separated
the mission of Javita from that of San
Fernando, the nearest distance to which
was twenty-five leagues in a straight line.
No other part of the country is known, but
the course of the rivers; nor does any man
ever attempt to go by land from one vil-
lage to another, were they only a few
leagues apart. But what difficulties shall
stay a mother, who is separated from her
children. The children of this devoted
and courageous woman are at San Fer-
nando de Atabapo; nature cries out, in-
citing her to find them again; she con-
ceives the possibility of executing her
project of delivering them from the hands
of Christians, and of bringing them back
to their father on the banks of the Gua-
viare. The Guahibi was carelessly guard-
ed in the caravansera. Her arms being
wounded, the Indians of Javita had loosen-
ed her bonds, unknown to the missionary and
the Alcades. She succeeded, by the help
of her teeth, in breaking them entirely;
disappeared during the night; and at the
fourth rising sun had actually arrived at
the mission of San Fernando, and was seen
hovering around the hut where her children
were confined. “What that wonderful wo-
man performed,” added the missionary,
who gave us this sad narrative, “the most
robust Indian would not have ventured to
undertake. She traversed the woods at a
season when the sky is constantly covered
with clouds, and the sun during whole
days appears but for a few minutes. The
course of the waters affords her no indica-
tion by which to direct her way! The in-
undations of the rivers forced her to go
far from the banks of the main stream,
through the midst of woods, where the
movement of the waters is almost imper-
ceptible. How often must she have been
stopped by the thorny lianas, that form a
net work around the trunks they entwine?
How often must she have swam across the
rivulets, that run into the Atabapo?—
This unfortunate woman was asked how
she had sustained herself during the four
days? She replied, that, exhausted with
fatigue, she could find no other nourish-
ment than those great black ants, called
vachacos, which climb the trees in long
bands, to suspend on them their resinous
nests! We pressed the missionary to tell us
whether the Guahibi had, after these unex-
ampled exertions, been allowed peaceably
to enjoy the happiness of remaining with
her children; and if any repentance had
followed this excess of cruelty, on the
part of her tormentors? He refused, how-
ever, to satisfy our curiosity; but at our
return from the Rio Negro, we learnt, that
the Indian mother had not even been al-
lowed time to cure her wounds, but was
again separated from her children, and sent
to one of the missions of the Upper Oroo-
noko, where death afforded her a kind re-
lease from her anxieties and sufferings. It
appeared that the unfortunate creature had,
at length, as is the custom with all savage
tribes in cases of overbearing calamity,
accelerated the approach of death, by re-
fusing all nourishment.
